name: Anjan Mukherjee
review_text:
*A Haunting Reminder of Indias Turbulent Past*

The Cellular Jail in Port Blair, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, is a poignant reminder of Indias struggle for independence. This former British colonial prison, now a national memorial, is a must-visit for history enthusiasts and anyone interested in understanding the countrys complex past.

The jails eerie atmosphere and crumbling walls whisper tales of the countless freedom fighters who suffered within its confines. The poignant museum, the infamous solitary cells, and the gallows all serve as a haunting reminder of the sacrifices made by Indias brave sons and daughters.

A visit to the Cellular Jail is a sobering experience that will leave you with a deeper appreciation for Indias hard-won freedom and a sense of reverence for the courageous men and women who fought for it.

Rating: 5/5

*Note:* Please be respectful of the sites history and significance. Dress modestly, and maintain silence within the premises.

The Light and Sound Show is particularly worth experiencing. It vividly narrates the atrocities committed by the British government and the relentless struggles of our freedom fighters. It almost feels like they are waving the Victorian flags once again**.

name: Vinit Kumar
review_text:
The Cellular Jail, located in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, is a powerful symbol of the Indian freedom struggle, representing the immense sacrifice of the freedom fighters who endured unimaginable cruelty under British rule. The jail, often referred to as Kala Pani was infamous for its isolation, and it housed many Indian freedom fighters who were considered a threat to the British Empire.
The freedom fighters who were incarcerated here included notable figures such as Batukeshwar Dutt, Veer Savarkar, Yogendra Shukla, and many others. They were subjected to harsh conditions, relentless punishment, solitary confinement, and forced labor.
One of the most emotionally impactful experiences at Cellular Jail today is the Light and Sound Show, which narrates the story of the freedom fighters who were imprisoned there. This show takes place in the evening and is designed to evoke deep emotions as it combines powerful visuals, sound, and light to narrate the history of the jail, highlighting the courage and endurance of the freedom fighters.

Stepping into this iconic structure, one is immediately transported back in time, feeling the weight of history within its walls. The highlight of the Cellular Jail experience is undoubtedly the spectacular light and sound show held in the evening. As the sun sets, the jail comes alive with a mesmerizing display of lights and lasers that narrate the heroic saga of Indias struggle for freedom. The narration, accompanied by soul-stirring music, creates a powerful and emotional journey through the pivotal moments of the independence movement.

The synchronized play of lights on the jails facade, coupled with the powerful storytelling, evokes a sense of pride and patriotism. It is a poignant tribute to the countless freedom fighters who endured unimaginable hardships within these very walls. The show not only educates visitors about Indias history but also leaves a lasting impact, instilling a deep appreciation for the sacrifices made for the nations independence.

In conclusion, the Cellular Jail and its spectacular light and sound show offer a profound and immersive experience that resonates with the spirit of Indias struggle for freedom. It is a must-visit destination for anyone seeking to connect with the rich historical tapestry of the country.

Most of his talk was about the importance of history and how we need to teach it to our children, who dont care about it anymore (in his mind). Too many of his opinions affected the quality of the information presented by him. name: Deepak Gaikwad
review_text:
Andaman Yatra

A holy pilgrimage to be done with devotion and patriotism as much as Kashi Yatra.

If you have read Majhi Janmthep, everything here is about the tortures suffered by many patriots including Krantisurya Savarkar, the conditions at that time and
Actually that time is standing in front of us.

Total 698 cells..
What kind of dungeons are the dungeons? A cellular prison structure with a tower in the center and 7 buildings in 7 directions around it.
With the vast ocean on one side, the jail building is a model of ideal architecture, but an architectural structure that reflects the inhumane atrocities of the British.
The sea is right next to it but its sight is not visible and the structure of the cell is such that not even a common man, let alone a bird, can be seen in the prison premises.
With only sunlight coming through a small window.
Even though Savarkars brothers are in the same jail, they have not seen each other for years, let alone meet them.
And at the same time, the internal structure shows demoralizing things. Inhumane punishments such as death row, cages given to the captives and the deafening cries while undergoing them....
All essence will be crushed. The fear of that time will bring a thorn in the body.....

Only 3 buildings out of 7 survive over time. But the same is beautifully preserved. Each building has three floors. At the same time, the photos and objects that will be taken during that time are worth seeing in the museum without missing a beat.....

In fact, at that time no prisoner was kept permanently in one cell. A detainee in one building was not remotely related to a detainee in another building. Savarkars long stay in the black cell on the second floor, which was punished by his long stay and which inspires us today, was the sight of the open gallows from this cell, the screams and cries of the prisoners who were suffering from inhuman hellish torture.
To be khachchi, to eat in the same cell, to sleep in the same room, to do all the body dharma..
Bapre! Just thinking about it makes you cringe and that time stands before your eyes and the hellish torture that Savarkar suffered.
By seeing reality, by remembering
Emotions burst...
Unknowingly, the edges of the eyes widen.
We entered the room with heavy hearts and pounding hearts.
Death appearing in different forms from moment to moment..
In this state
Eternal Me .. Infinite Me ..
Awadhya I am good
Fire net Majsi
Nor the rock pierces
Im afraid
death runs away

Savarkar who says...
What kind of bone is this man...
Maybe only God can tell..

While he was living in the dungeon under the torture of hell, how could he have created Sahastra Ovas epic poem Kamala on the walls of the dungeon with his supernatural talent, without a pen and paper.

If the bricks, walls, stones and soil here started talking, then every event here would have been told with great pride and passion.
What to say to this talent and intelligence!

The hands were unknowingly joined while bowing before the picture placed in front.. the dam of emotions broke .. and then Savarkars own lines came to the rescue even while giving way to the emotions.

* took Majsi back to motherland..*
*The ocean yearned for life, the ocean yearned...*
